ygData.subject: Re: [neat] New paper on why modules evolve, and how to evolve modular artificial neural networks
ygData.msgSnippet: Hello Alexandre, Thanks for the very kind words about our paper. I am glad you like it and think it is helpful. Please see my answers to your questions below.

From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] New paper on why modules evolve, and how to evolve modular artificial neural networks
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=464818732; y=dyNRwePljCdcT15OogCQyLtErVkD1RXu-BieGyXTMZJXyzYtfLdv
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune


--Apple-Mail=_5CAD7278-07B2-4251-8813-DFCC68B8168E
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset=windows-1252

Hello Alexandre,

Thanks for the very kind words about our paper. I am glad=
 you like it and think it is helpful. Please see my answers to your questio=
ns below. 

>   Simple, clean experiment, with sharp results, congrats on t=
hat, definitely
> a step forward ! Of course, it begs for more questions. I=
 would love to hear
> you on such (fairly open) questions
> 
>    1) Do you=
 think that selection pressure for low connectivity is sufficient in
> itse=
lf to evolve large coherent networks, or is it just a piece of the puzzle ?=


Our results suggest that a connection cost is sufficient to produce modul=
arity. Moreover, we found that it produced functional modules that solve su=
bproblems in the domain, which is an important and positive sign. Finally, =
the presence of those modules sped up adaptation to a new environment, indi=
cating evolvability. A next step is to see if the same result occurs with l=
arger, more complex networks, and on more complex problems. I hope our resu=
lts will generalize to larger networks, and I think there are good reasons =
to expect that, but it remains to be experimentally tested. We are studying=
 that issue at the moment, actually, but I do not have results to report ye=
t. 

Thus, I do think a connection cost produces modularity, but modularity=
 is not the only piece of the puzzle in terms of evolving large, structural=
ly organized networks. For that we need regularity  (see my IEEE TEC paper =
with Ken and others), which can come from a good encoding like CPPNs, hiera=
rchy, better search algorithms, incorporating neural plasticity, etc. (the =
list goes on and on). In that sense, this result is just a piece of the puz=
zle, but I do think it is a very important piece. 

>    2) Do you see your=
 work as an indication that any approach biased to low
> connectivity would=
 reproduce the result ? Or does the way you guys enforced
> this bias matte=
rs ?
> 


Our experiments suggest to me that the technique is quite general=
 and is not sensitive to the specifics of the implementation. Here are some=
 reasons I believe that
We started with the network cost being a function o=
f the summed length of all connections. Modularity evolved, but one might t=
hink that it did because the problem has geometric separation (the left and=
 right sides of the retina are physically separated), such that punishing l=
ong connections is akin to punishing the merging of information from the le=
ft and right sides. To see if that geometric separation made a difference, =
we randomized the locations of the retina inputs, and found that modularity=
 still evolved with a connection cost based on summed length. (Fig. S7B htt=
p://goo.gl/8aHIc). 
We then tested whether the length of connections was th=
e key difference, or whether modularity would evolve even with a penalty fo=
r just the number of connections. We found that just as much modularity evo=
lved in this treatment (although there were a few subtle differences discus=
sed in the paper). 
We also tested different strengths of selective pressur=
e for cost function (Fig. S5 http://goo.gl/8aHIc) and tested in static and =
changing environments (Fig. S5); and we found that the modularity result wa=
s surprisingly robust to experimental parameters. 
Experimental data aside,=
 there is a good reason why a connection cost leads to modularity. A connec=
tion cost leads to sparsity, and a much higher percentage of sparse network=
s are modular (vs. the percentage of networks that are modular in more full=
y connected networks). Try thinking of sparse, non-modular networks: they a=
re the exceptions. Now, try thinking of non-modular, near-fully-connected n=
etworks: they're everywhere! Modular networks are very rare when there are =
a lot of connections in a network. To test whether these intuitions are tru=
e, we randomly generated networks with different costs (e.g. number of conn=
ections) and plotted them (Fig. S12 here: http://goo.gl/8aHIc). I think thi=
s plot may be one of the key plots in the whole paper, as it shows that *ev=
en before selection* networks that have fewer connections will be more modu=
lar, so any means of pressuring evolution towards networks with fewer conne=
ctions will likely lead to modularity. 

In conclusion, we saw modularity s=
how up in a many different implementations of the experiment and with diffe=
rent parameters, and we validated the reason why we should expect that mini=
mizing connections leads to modularity. All of these reasons combine to mak=
e me think the result will generalize well. That said, you never know until=
 more experiments are conducted, which is why I am excited to hear how this=
 technique works for others, as well as see how it works for us in future e=
xperiments. 

Thanks for the nice questions. 

Best regards,
Jeff Clune

As=
sistant Professor
Computer Science
University of Wyoming
jclune@...
je=
ffclune.com

On Feb 6, 2013, at 6:33 PM, Alexandre Devert <marmakoide@yahoo=
.fr> wrote:

> 
> Hi,
> 
>   Simple, clean experiment, with sharp results, =
congrats on that, definitely
> a step forward ! Of course, it begs for more=
 questions. I would love to hear
> you on such (fairly open) questions
> 
>=
    1) Do you think that selection pressure for low connectivity is suffici=
ent in
> itself to evolve large coherent networks, or is it just a piece of=
 the puzzle ?
>    2) Do you see your work as an indication that any approa=
ch biased to low
> connectivity would reproduce the result ? Or does the wa=
y you guys enforced
> this bias matters ?
> 
> To me 
> 1) =3D> Part of the=
 puzzle. Should see how well it scales for increasingly
> complex task, whe=
n the connection graph gets bigger. A randomized 
> search process on large=
 graph sounds not so efficient, need something to guide it.
> I advocate co=
nstruction process that have a feedback from what the neuron 
> network is =
computing. Don't know how to do it without creepling computational
> cost t=
ho...
> 2) =3D> I guess that the bias alone is enough, the way to introduce=
 it might
> not be such a big deal. 
> 
> Again, great work, very helpful c=
ontribution :)
> 
> Alex
>  
> Dr. Devert Alexandre
> Researcher at the Nat=
ure Inspired Computation and Applications Laboratory (NICAL)
> Lecturer at =
School Of Software Engineering of USTC
> ----------------------------------=
------------------
> Homepage : http://www.marmakoide.org
> ---------------=
-------------------------------------
> 166 Renai Road, Dushu Lake Higher E=
ducation Town
> Suzhou Industrial Park,
> Suzhou, Jiangsu, People's Republi=
c of China
> From: Jeff Clune <jclune@...>
> To: neat users group gro=
up <neat@yahoogroups.com> 
> Cc: Jean-Baptiste Mouret <mouret@...>=
; Hod Lipson <hod.lipson@...> 
> Sent: Thursday, February 7, 2013 1=
:57 AM
> Subject: [neat] New paper on why modules evolve, and how to evolve=
 modular artificial neural networks
> 
>  
> Hello all,
> 
> I'm extremely =
pleased to announce a new paper on a subject that many--including myself--t=
hink is critical to making significant progress in our field: the evolution=
 of modularity. 
> 
> Jean-Baptiste Mouret, Hod Lipson and I have a new pap=
er that 
> 
> 1) sheds light on why modularity may evolve in biological net=
works (e.g. neural, genetic, metabolic, protein-protein, etc.)
> 
> 2) prov=
ides a simple technique for evolving neural networks that are modular and h=
ave increased evolvability, in that they adapt faster to new environments. =
The modules that formed solved subproblems in the domain. 
> 
> Cite: Clune=
 J, Mouret J-B, Lipson H (2013) The evolutionary origins of modularity. Pro=
ceedings of the Royal Society B. 280: 20122863. http://dx.doi.org/10.1098/r=
spb.2012.2863 (pdf)
> 
> Abstract: A central biological question is how nat=
ural organisms are so evolvable (capable of quickly adapting to new environ=
ments). A key driver of evolvability is the widespread modularity of biolog=
ical networks=97their organization as functional, sparsely connected subuni=
ts=97but there is no consensus regarding why modularity itself evolved. Alt=
hough most hypotheses assume indirect selection for evolvability, here we d=
emonstrate that the ubiquitous, direct selection pressure to reduce the cos=
t of connections between network nodes causes the emergence of modular netw=
orks. Computational evolution experiments with selection pressures to maxim=
ize network performance and minimize connection costs yield networks that a=
re significantly more modular and more evolvable than control experiments t=
hat only select for performance. These results will catalyse research in nu=
merous disciplines, such as neuroscience and genetics, and enhance our abil=
ity to harness evolution for engineering purposes.
> 
> Video: http://www.y=
outube.com/watch?feature=3Dplayer_embedded&v=3DSG4_aW8LMng
> 
> There has b=
een some nice coverage of this work in the popular press, in case you are i=
nterested:
> 
> National Geographic: http://phenomena.nationalgeographic.co=
m/2013/01/30/the-parts-of-life/MIT's Technology Review: http://www.technolo=
gyreview.com/view/428504/computer-scientists-reproduce-the-evolution-of-evo=
lvability/ Fast Company: http://www.fastcompany.com/3005313/evolved-brains-=
robots-creep-closer-animal-learningCornell Chronicle: http://www.news.corne=
ll.edu/stories/Jan13/modNetwork.htmlScienceDaily: http://www.sciencedaily.c=
om/releases/2013/01/130130082300.htm
> 
> Please let me know what you think=
 and if you have any questions. I hope this work will help our field move f=
orward!
> 
> 
> 
> Best regards,
> Jeff Clune
> 
> Assistant Professor
> Co=
mputer Science
> University of Wyoming
> jclune@...
> jeffclune.com
> =

> 
> 
> 
> 


--Apple-Mail=_5CAD7278-07B2-4251-8813-DFCC68B8168E

Content-Type: text/html;
	charset=windows-1252

    <div id=3D"yiv1159911870ygrp-text">
      
      
      <div><div><=
div><span class=3D"yiv1159911870Apple-style-span" style=3D"border-collapse:=
separate;"><div>Hello all,</div><div><br></div><div>I'm extremely pleased t=
o announce a new paper on a subject that many--including myself--think is c=
ritical to making significant progress in our field: the evolution of modul=
arity. </div><div><br></div><div>Jean-Baptiste Mouret, Hod Lipson and =
I have a new paper that </div><div><br></div><div>1) sheds light on wh=
y modularity may evolve in biological networks (e.g. neural, genetic, metab=
olic, protein-protein, etc.)</div><div><br></div><div>2) provides a simple =
technique for evolving neural networks that are modular and have increased =
evolvability, in that they adapt faster to new environments. The modules th=
at formed solved subproblems in the domain. </div><div><br></div>Cite:=
 Clune J, Mouret J-B, Lipson H (2013) The evolutionary origins of modu=
larity. Proceedings of the Royal Society B. 280:
 20122863. <a rel=3D"=
nofollow" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://dx.doi.org/10.1098/rspb.2012.286=
3"><span style=3D"color:rgb(0, 102, 204);">http://dx.doi.org/10.1098/rspb.2=
012.2863</span></a> (<a rel=3D"nofollow" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"htt=
p://jeffclune.com/publications/2013-CluneEtAl-EvolutionaryOriginsModularity=
-RoyalSociety.pdf"><span style=3D"color:rgb(0, 102, 204);">pdf</span></a>)<=
div style=3D"color:rgb(24, 24, 24);"><br></div><div style=3D"color:rgb(24, =
24, 24);">Abstract: A central biological question is how natural organisms =
are so evolvable (capable of quickly adapting to new environments). A key d=
river of evolvability is the widespread modularity of biological networks=
=97their organization as functional, sparsely connected subunits=97but ther=
e is no consensus regarding why modularity itself evolved. Although most hy=
potheses assume indirect selection for evolvability, here we demonstrate th=
at the ubiquitous, direct selection pressure to reduce the cost
 of connect=
ions between network nodes causes the emergence of modular networks. Comput=
ational evolution experiments with selection pressures to maximize network =
performance and minimize connection costs yield networks that are significa=
ntly more modular and more evolvable than control experiments that only sel=
ect for performance. These results will catalyse research in numerous disci=
plines, such as neuroscience and genetics, and enhance our ability to harne=
ss evolution for engineering purposes.</div><div><br></div><div>Video:&nbsp=
;<a rel=3D"nofollow" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://www.youtube.com/watch=
?feature=3Dplayer_embedded&v=3DSG4_aW8LMng">http://www.youtube.com/watc=
h?feature=3Dplayer_embedded&v=3DSG4_aW8LMng</a></div><div><br></div><di=
v>There has been some nice coverage of this work in the popular press, in c=
ase you are interested:</div><div><br></div><span style=3D"">National Geogr=
aphic: <a rel=3D"nofollow" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://phenomena.=
nationalgeographic.com/2013/01/30/the-parts-of-life/">http://phenomena.nati=
onalgeographic.com/2013/01/30/the-parts-of-life/</a></span><font color=3D"#=
040404">MIT's Technology Review:</font><span style=3D"color:rgb(71, 135, 25=
5);"> <a rel=3D"nofollow" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://www.technol=
ogyreview.com/view/428504/computer-scientists-reproduce-the-evolution-of-ev=
olvability/">http://www.technologyreview.com/view/428504/computer-scientist=
s-reproduce-the-evolution-of-evolvability/</a> </span><span style=3D""=
>Fast Company: <a rel=3D"nofollow" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://ww=
w.fastcompany.com/3005313/evolved-brains-robots-creep-closer-animal-learnin=
g">http://www.fastcompany.com/3005313/evolved-brains-robots-creep-closer-an=
imal-learning</a></span><span style=3D"">Cornell Chronicle: <a rel=3D"=
nofollow" target=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://www.news.cornell.edu/stories/Jan=
13/modNetwork.html">http://www.news.cornell.edu/stories/Jan13/modNetwork.ht=
ml</a></span><span style=3D"">ScienceDaily: <a rel=3D"nofollow" target=
=3D"_blank" href=3D"http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/01/1301300823=
00.htm">http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2013/01/130130082300.htm</a></=
span><div><br></div><div>Please let me know what you think and if you have =
any questions. I hope this work will help our field move forward!</div><div=
><br></div></span></div></div></div><div><span class=3D"yiv1159911870Apple-=
